title: Sea Life Aquarium at Arizona Mills in Tempe adding new Colorado River exhibit for kids

CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE An aquarium that opened seven years ago at Arizona Mills in Tempe is upping its game with a new $1 million feature aimed at kids.
The Sea Life Aquarium's Colorado River Adventure broke ground on Feb. 17 and should open in late spring.
The exhibit will tell the story of the Colorado River from its start in the Rocky Mountains to its end at the Sea of Cortez in Mexico.
The exhibit will include a large water play table with hands-on features, aquarium officials said. Guests will be able to pump, twist and turn water while learning about conservation.
Only a short drive away from the Sea Life Aquarium is Scottsdale's OdySea Aquarium, which opened last July.
Sea Life spokeswoman Elizabeth Mathews said there's not much competition between the two because she said aquariums work with each other to promote conservation.
"We really focus on conservation and how we can protect the environment from a mainland city that's not even near an ocean," Mathews said.
She said there's been a growing interest in bringing ocean life to the Valley and the exhibit aims to capitalize on that to educate guests about conservation.
MORE: Take a peek inside these metro Phoenix aquariums 
Sea Life also has a freshwater exhibit that houses creatures native to Arizona's Salt River, a tidepool where guests can touch creatures such as sea stars and urchins, stingray and seahorse exhibits, a live coral reef, and an ocean view exhibit that's home to sharks and a rescued sea turtle.
Mathews said the latest exhibit will be aimed at children, who they hope will take away important lessons about humans' impact on ocean life.
"It's good for kids to learn at a young age how local conservation efforts can help impact the ocean environment," Mathews said.
Mathews said the exhibit will teach kids how to help protect their favorite sea creatures by doing things like picking up trash to prevent it from entering waterways.
“The Colorado River exhibit ups the ante when it comes to interactive, hands-on learning and fun,” Joanna Hobday, Sea Life Arizona Aquarium’s general manager, said in a written statement. “It’s a great way for kids to learn more about their local waterways and the animals that call the Sea of Cortez home.”
The exhibit is expected to open in late spring.
